Manx: Ta cooinaght aym er dooinney va’n thie echey heese ec yn cheyllys, as veagh guillyn aegey Chreneash chaglym ayn Jedoonee. Veagh paart jeh’n sleih gra “Juan Illiam Ned” rish, as feallagh elley yn “Woy Wooar”.
English: I recall a man who’s house was down at the Sound, and the young lads of Cregneash would gather there on Sundays. Some of them would call him “Juan Illiam Ned” and others [would call him] the “Woy Wooar”.
Diplomatic: Ta cooinniagh aym er dhonney van thie eck eh heese eck yn chellys, as vagh gillyn aigey chrenaish chaglym ayn jedoonee Vagh paart jeh yn sleih gra “joan illiam ned” rish, as follagh elley yn “woy wooar”,

Manx: Va ennym yn ven echey “Alish” as va kiare guillyn echey, va fer jeu “Illiam Beg” fer elley “Juan ny Howe,” “Ned mooar” as yn trass “Mwillar Alish”.
English: His wife’s name was “Alish” and he had four boys, one of them was “Little Illiam”, another “Juan of the Howe”, “Big Ned” and the third “Alish’s Miller”.
Diplomatic: Va ennym yn ven eck eh “Alish” as va kair gillyn ecke, va fer jiu “illiam beg” fer elley “joan ny howe.” “Ned mooar” as yn trass “mwillar Alish”

Manx: V'eh freayl un chabble va enmyssit “George”. Veagh ad bwoalley yn arroo ayns yn thie v’ad cummal ayn.
English: He kept one horse, who was named “George”. They would thrash the corn in the house they were living in.
Diplomatic: Ve freayl un chabble va enmyssit “george”, vagh ad bwoalley yn arroo ayns yn thie va’d coammal ayn,

Manx: Tha cooinnagh aym er gholl marish my Ayr gys thie yn woy wooar, vagh paart jeh ny bunneeyn ayns cornail yn thie dy mennick, as tra vagh yn woy wooar lesh y yenneeyr vagh eh lhie er yn arroo;
English: I remember going with my father to Woy Wooar’s house. There’d often be some of the sheaves in the corner of the house, and when the Woy Wooar would have had his dinner he’d be lying on the corn.
Diplomatic: Tha cooinnagh aym er gholl marish my Ayr gys thie yn woy wooar, vagh paart jeh ny bonnyen ayns cornail yn thie dy mennick, as tra vagh yn woy wooar lesh y yenneeyr vagh eh lhie er yn arroo;

Manx: Veagh yn bock George cheet stiagh ny cheayrtyn dy hayrtyn lane beeal jeh yn coonlagh, as un cheayrt haink eh, as ghow eh holt er folt yn Woy Wooar marish yn choonlagh, son va’n folt echey feer liauyr, as ren yn bock lesh yn dorrys tayrn yn Woy Wooar marish; geamagh dy jinnagh eh brishey ny craueyn ayn, as myr shen ren yn bock sleidey eh ersooyl; gys ren yn folt chur raad.
English: George the gelding would be coming in sometimes to grab a mouthful of the straw, and one time he came, and he took a hold on the Woy Wooar’s hair together with the straw, because his hair was so long, and the gelding made towards the door pulling the Woy Wooar with him; shouting that he would break his bones, and so the gelding dragged him away; until the hair gave way.
Diplomatic: vagh yn bock goeorge cheet stiagh ny cheayrtyn dy hartyn lane beeal jeh yn coonlagh, as un cheayrt haink eh, as ghow eh holt er folt yn woy wooar marish yn coonlagh, son va yn folt eck eh feer louyr, as ren yn bock lesh yn dorrys tayrn yn woywooar marish; geamagh dy jannagh eh brishey ny crauen ayn, as mor shen ren yn bock sleidey eh ersooyl; gys ren yn folt chur raad,

Manx: Te feer lickly dy row eh ny s’kiarailagh ny lurg shen.
English: It’s likely that he was more careful after that.
Diplomatic: Te feer lickly dy row eh ny scaaraillagh ny lurg shen.
